(I'm reviewing this pre-Shrooms Update, post Halloween Update.)

I want to say I really like this game so far and I'm excited to see where it goes in the future. As it stands right now, it's not perfect but definitely promising. Some of the features could be improved before the final release of the game such as:

- Making the Cartel have more of a presence in Hyland Point
- Quality of life improvements to the Delivery and Dealers apps (which are confirmed to come in the future)
- Making employees faster and smarter (Chemists are expensive, yet lazy)
- More level up rewards for the late game (I'm sure this will come eventually though with new weapons, improved workstations, etc)
- Bug fixes (I'm sure 99% of the bugs will be fixed before release though)

Maybe the Cartel could have "events" around the map, like maybe if your dealers are being attacked, you have a couple hours to go and defend them or else your dealer will lose their product. And if you fend them off, you can lower their influence over the area. Stuff like this could help alleviate the problem of the Cartel dealers only showing up at 11:59 pm, and very occasionally ambushing you. The ambushes are very rare as of right now, which makes it harder to reduce the Cartel influence and unlock new areas. 
I actually got stuck in my first save file because I had unlocked all the customers in Westville and then betrayed the cartel, forcing me to wait every night at 11:59 for a Cartel dealer to pop out of their hideout so I can attack them.

I can't recommend this game enough. Tyler (the developer) is so transparent and communicative with his community in informing us of delays in updates and letting us have a voice in what update will be worked on and released next. 

You can easily put hundreds of hours into this game, and the fact that it's still in early access baffles me to this day. You can play single player or with friends. I enjoy playing single player because I like playing all of the roles in the game and learning all aspects of it. You can make marijuana, cocaine, meth, and soon shrooms (in the newest update coming early to mid-December 2025). You can create so many different strains and combinations by mixing ingredients and name all the different strains yourself. This game just has everything you can possibly think of; I can't speak positively of it enough. Tyler recently released a cartel update, so now there is a cartel (Benzies) that warns you of selling drugs on "their" turf. You can either reject their proposal to work for them or accept. It makes the game feel more dangerous and fun, honestly. If you reject their proposal, they make your job of selling drugs a lot more dangerous for not only you but also your distributors.

Again, I love this game so much. I go through bouts where I get a little bored and then come back a couple of months later to new content and get addicted again. Is it worth the money? 100%, absolutely. You're also supporting a really awesome dev.

Schedule 1 is basically the game I always wanted after watching Breaking Bad. It is not exactly what I once imagined, but it absolutely scratches that itch. This is probably the first time I felt compelled to review (not because to complete the steam award badge), simply because it‚Äôs that good.

The hook hits fast, and yes it is very addictive (pun intended). Content is still limited at the moment (pre-Shroom update, post-Halloween update), but even in its current form it easily offers 100+ hours of gameplay if it grabs you. 

Of course, being early access means there is still a long way ahead, but that‚Äôs part of the fun. The developer is very transparent with the process, sharing progress openly. The community is active too, and and watching other people's creativity in their builds/run and playstyles makes it even more engaging.

All in all, Schedule 1 is already a strong game that has a lot of potential, and I cant wait for more. *violently milking the H*.

The game feels really nice to play. It's pretty in depth for what it is and needs some planning how to progress and sell your drugs.

Building up your empire feels rewarding too, you start small and become powerful step by step. Progression is somewhat time-gated but it's not too annoying or harsh.

I like the updates that are coming out albeit they feel a bit slow and rushed at times. The game became quite buggy in multiplayer which makes only the host eligible to pay off debt, pay the cartel, buy property, etc. That really sucks but can usually be fixed with restarting the session or waiting for a bug fix update.

For the price it's great value and I really wish for the game to get harder and more risky. Police feels braindead at times - they are no threat. Maybe a helicopter or SWAT units could mix things up? The cartel is a great idea, just not that fleshed out sadly.

All in all, despite my criticism, it's still a recommendation!

Schedule 1 is one of those games you pick up when you want to dive into a life of crime and chaos. It really captures the thrill of living like a cartel lord or feeling like you're in the Breaking Bad TV show sitting on piles of cash, hanging out with your crew, dodging cops, and delivering your goods. The game makes you feel like you're breaking the rules, doing things you probably shouldn‚Äôt, like mixing gasoline into your concoctions and hoping the customers don‚Äôt notice.

It brings back memories of classic gangster games, similar to the earlier Saints Row titles, where you truly felt like part of a gang. The gameplay is satisfying and immersive, especially in co-op mode, where playing with friends creates memorable moments that you find yourself sharing in real life, sometimes making people question what you were up to the night before.

Overall, I give Schedule 1 a 10 out of 10. It‚Äôs fun, engaging, and the cooperative play amplifies the chaos and enjoyment. Whether you're managing your empire or just goofing around with friends, it‚Äôs a game that delivers a unique blend of strategy, humor, and crime sandbox action.

First of all, I am writing this review using Google Translate because my English is not good enough, I hope it is understandable.

The game is excellent, but it has some shortcomings.

- The language options need to be expanded.

- I think it would be better if the game have a sense of action and tension.

-NPCs who die or faint should be removed after a certain period of time. They only disappear when we sleep, and if we kill the cops at night, the whole place becomes safe. When cops die, I think new police should arrive at patrol positions a few hours later.

- The tutorial section is weak; players learn by searching the internet or watching YouTube. (I'm not talking about recipes. I just want to assign tasks to workers, how to use which stall or product, etc.)

- NPC animations need to be improved.

- The Benzies family is my enemy, but I rarely see anyone from this family in the city. Every two or three days in the game, three or four people attack me or my vendors. Other than that, they have no other activity. I gave my vendor a weapon, but he still sometimes says he can't defend himself and loses supplies and money.

- A new city, a new cartel, or a new street gang could be added. The city's thugs will grow from small to large, and we'll either get along with them or we won't and make enemies.

- NPCs should be careful after 6:00 PM during curfew. They should walk on streets and other places where the police can't see them. But they just walk right past the police, and the police don't do anything.

- When NPCs attack us, the police don't do anything, but when we attack them, they chase us away.

- Sometimes it would be nice to have different NPC scenarios. Fights between our vendors and Benzies Family vendors, fights with the police, etc.

-Gunshots, echoes, etc. need to be improved.

This game is outright amazing.

The only issue I have with it is it needs a better product organization scheme. The naming and list of products is very nebulous and it's easy to get lost looking for your mixes.

For instance, if I create an 8-ingredient mix, I'd like there to be an inventory screen that shows the mixing order visually, rather than just naming the upgrade on the tool tip, because then you have to search your whole list for the next mix that can be anywhere in the list.

Also, the speed of production is much faster than the speed of procurement of ingredients, even with deliveries. It becomes a massive chore to restock. Basically, the product creation is extremely streamlined and automated, but the restocking of goods has no automation for it really whatsoever. You use all available employees to create a robust mixing automated process where you have very little left over for the limited methods for restocking. Perhaps have managers have 8 delivery paths (because there are up to 8 ingredients able to be mixed in a product), or have the delivery spots have some menu options on what items that come in should be dropped off to what shelves, and then have a manager be able to be assigned to that delivery spot. Or, have a "Driver" employee that can take care of it outright.

It is these two reasons mentioned that I have not come back to the game after "completing" it.

This is definitely an instance where I wish I could give more than a simple up down, yes no review. Right now, I am leaning no until some things are fixed (I am aware this is early access). 

First, the pros. The mini-games are addicting as hell. New mini-games and products are unlocked at a pretty good clip, so it hasn't gotten boring yet. The gameplay loop is satisfying as well, for the most part (caveat below). Experiment with different concoctions, expand your operation, become a kingpin. Fun, straightforward, and clean game loop.

However, it is the recent cartel update that has pushed this to a no for me (for now). Simply put, the cartel update is broken. The general idea is that there's a cartel in town and you need to reduce their influence (by tagging buildings, fighting off ambushes, dealing with the cartel dealers, etc.) in order to expand your operations into different parts of town. On paper, it is a cool mechanic that I am excited to see them continue to expand. 

In practice, however, this mechanic as it currently stands is broken to hell. Tagging is supposed to reduce cartel influence, and it does, but not in the starting area. So you have to fight off ambushes and take out the cartel dealer to reduce influence. Should be easy, but ambushes are so few and far between that I've been playing for several in game weeks between ambushes. When I am ambushed, its by four, five, or six dudes and I just get mowed down before I have a chance to defend myself. There doesn't seem to be much of a rhyme or reason to how ambushes work. I've seen folks say that ambushes are more likely after completing a deal, however, I played several days where I was slinging the rocks like crazy and I wasn't attacked once (although my Westview dealer, despite being strapped, gets assaulted CONSTANTLY and loses me a ton of product and money). I now spend most of my day running around town to all the ambush spots and then going home disappointed after not getting ambushed. This makes the mid-game a grind, in a very bad way. I feel stuck with really no way to move into other territories. I'm still making money hand over fist, but without expansion it just seems like a waste. 

Cartel dealers are another way that you are supposed to be able to reduce influence and after running around town, waiting at the places they supposedly spawn at for days (before midnight, at midnight, after midnight, I've tried everything), I have yet to see a single dealer let alone have the opportunity to eliminate one. I've removed customers from my dealers, still nothing. 

To the developers, you have an amazing game here. Truly, it is so fun and engaging. However, until the cartel mechanic is fixed I cannot recommend this game. For suggestions:

- I would make ambushes slightly more common (not a daily thing certainly but often enough to make the progression meaningful and exciting)
- I would overhaul the cartel dealer mechanics. For instance, they could be more visible and be taunting you  and stuff but you can't touch them during the day because cops and witnesses etc. You could hunt them down at night
- Don't tie spray paint to level achievement. Currently, spray paint is granted at level. Instead, I would recommend having it refresh daily (or weekly). This way if all else fails, you can slowly start to reduce influence even if ambushes and dealer stuff is getting slow. 

TL;DR Cartel update broken, wait for them to fix it before buying

[h1] A good early game, but disappointing development cycle lets down mid-to-late game! [/h1]

Liked it at first, [i] obviously [/i] considering i have 260 hours; i would say that this game is worth what it costs. But i did buy this game after looking through the frequency of patch notes and updates, and at the time (back in April/May), i think it was once every few weeks, which i figured was pretty good even [i] if [/i] the game wasn't completely perfect, it'd get there in due course - i bought this game thinking its development cycle was going to be (generally) smooth.

The problem is, is that the updates are super slow and what updates we [b] DO [/b] get - are left to [i] 'community votes' [/i] , which are the [i] stupidest [/i] thing i've seen, we DO NOT need 'shrooms' right now, [i] why? [/i] because this product will suffer the EXACT same bugs, issues and flaws that currently burden mid to late game for EVERY other product already in the game, for instance, supposing drivers were released and on top of that we got recurring deliveries, this would alleviate the hassle of travelling between multiple properties - taking inventory, and ordering more supplies, it would make the game arguably [b] way [/b] more fun.

If you look at the newest update, it adds the sewers: an alternative way to travel that avoids police and cartel - that is utterly pointless and no player will ever use with the current state of police and cartel. I'm being rather anecdotal here - as im not sure how others experiences with the cartel have gone, but ambushes happened to me AT MOST - once a week and allowed you to run away or fight (rather easily). The police are no better, if you literally kill all of them - or block the pathfinding of police, they cease to be a problem or challenge; i highly doubt a police overhaul would ever fix this, given that the cartel update really didn't live up to people's expectations.

[b] [i] I get that Tyler is working by himself and he has made a great game, but if you're going to dripfeed content to a game, [u] commit to it [/u], don't just disappear for months. [/i] [/b]
